newsitem.title: NAMIBIA: Namibia and Germany sign two loan agreements.
newsitem.headline: Namibia and Germany sign two loan agreements.

text.p: Namibia and Germany on Thursday signed two financial co-operation agreements, providing loan funds worth N$93.8 million for two development projects.
The loan will allow for the modernisation of the Walvis Bay Harbour and the expansion of Windhoek's water reclamation plant.
The extension of Walvis Bay, Namibia's foremost commercial port, will be funded with N$35.4 million. The project aims to expand the container terminal and upgrade the tanker quay.
The remaining N$58.4 million will be spent on expanding Windhoek's existing waste water reclamation plant.
Director General of the National Planning Commission, Sarah Kuukongelwa who was signing the agreements on behalf of the Nambian government, stressed the importance of both projects.
She said that because of Namibia's critical water shortage, managing the country's scarce water resources was a priority.
She added that when modernised, Walvis Bay should attract more trade and stimulate exports.
Describing the funds as "a favourable loan," Kuukongelwa said it was granted at an interest rate of two percent per annum with a maturity of 30 years including a grace period of 10 years.
The funds will go to the Namibian government, which will then loan the money at a market-oriented interest rate to the municipality of Windhoek amd the Namibian port authority.
German ambassador to Namibia Hanns Schumacher said both projects were commercially viable.

He pointed out that the Windhoek municipality had already drastically restructured its water tariffs to be able to pay for the loan, while the port authority was already operating at a considerable profit.
Germany is the largest bilateral donor to Namibia and is already supporting several large infrastructural projects such as telecommunications, water supply and roads.
